intro: Castilleja pilosa var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy leaf Indian paintbrush, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its bright red or orange flowers that resemble paintbrushes. The plant has slender, leafless stems that often grow in association with other plants, deriving some of its nutrients from its host. Its leaves are hairy and alternate, typically appearing in clusters near the base of the plant. Castilleja pilosa var. pilosa is often found in open habitats such as meadows and woodlands, where it thrives in well-drained soils.
